     Encik Mansor Haji Sukaimi (Kampong Kembangan)( In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, in line with our policy of encouraging the use of English, I therefore wish to speak in English on this debate.

    (In English) On 14th March 1979, I wrote to six principals of primary schools in Kampong Kembangan and Kampong Ubi constituencies and also to 20 community leaders in these two constituencies urging them to carefully study Dr Goh's report which was released in instalments through the press and RTS. I also asked them to seek the views of their teachers and friends. The response I had was most gratifying. 109 teachers and residents met me in four separate dialogue sessions on 24th and 26th March 1979 and, from these sessions, I managed to prepare a report which summarises their views and comments. The report contains 46 recommendations and comments. In these dialogue sessions, I invited them to express the views or comments freely. Then I presented my views and sought their comments and verifications.

    After the discussions, I prepared a draft report which was then referred back to 17 of the original 109 and together we went through the draft, paragraph by paragraph. Some of the participants in the dialogue sessions who were teachers did a great service to me. We finished the redraft at 12.15 a.m. on 27th March 1979. With the amendments and additions, I prepared the final paper on 27th March 1979, and I submitted it to the Hon. Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education on the same day.

Column: 157



    Mr Speaker, Sir, I have consulted the Clerk of Parliament who told me that you have very kindly allowed me to formally table this report. I understand that the Clerk had made additional copies for distribution to Members.

    I am happy to inform you, Mr Speaker, Sir, that during the dialogue sessions, we discussed very freely. The mood was most reassuring, quite unlike the tense anxiety which prevailed in previous meetings I had with my constituents on education policies. This change I thought was a good sign and it indeed facilitated the discussions I had with my constituents.

    Since the report will form an appendix (Cols. 221 - 244) to my presentation today, I will not go through each and every comment contained in the report. I only need to highlight six issues:
appendix - VIEWS AND COMMENTS FROM TEACHERS AND RESIDENTS OF KAMPONG KEMBANGAN CONSTITUENCY ON DR GOH KENG SWEE'S "REPORT ON THE MINISTRY OF EDUCATION 1978" (Cols. 221 - 244)


(1) Governing Principles in Implementation

    It is clear from the report, and from Dr Goh's statements that there is still so much preparatory work to be done. In Section 3.1 of Chapter 6, Dr Goh and his team recognised the need to do a more detailed study and preparatory work on the new curriculum, streaming procedures, formats of examinations, IQ tests, text books, allocation of teachers, briefings to principals and teachers, and promotion programme to explain the new system to the public and parents. As there is this assurance, it is perhaps not necessary for me to discuss this preparatory work in detail. However, it is useful if we set out some principles and guidelines to ensure that the preparatory work is implemented smoothly, expeditiously and correctly.

    In paragraph 51 of our report, my constituents and I have offered nine governing principles. We have, in particular, urged that the Ministry formulates an integrated action plan to govern the implementation and follow-up actions. We thought that if the Ministry could produce the network similar to the techniques applied in Programme Evaluation

Column: 158

and Review Technique, or more popularly known as PERT, I think we have a better chance to identify and know the critical components of the follow-up work and will ensure proper co-ordination, monitoring, and control. With regard to IQ tests, Dr Goh could perhaps ask one of his officials to review the article by Robert B. McCall entitled "Childhood IQ as Predictors of Educational and Occupational Status". In this article, McCall discusses the review done by C. Jencks and his colleagues on the sparse evidence on the predictive validity of IQ tests, and that the correlations between school-age IQ and the indices of adult educational and occupational success rarely exceed 60, not high enough for practical purposes requiring long-term prediction.

(2) Need for Continuing Dialogue

    Mr Speaker, Sir, my constituents and I heartily welcome the Government's decision to subject the Study Team's plan for debate in Parliament. This is an enrichment of our parliamentary tradition. We strongly recommend that Government continues this opportunity for dialogue and debate particularly on selected key issues of the Study Team's proposals. Our recommendations for continuing this dialogue are outlined in paragraphs 5a-i of our paper.

(3) End-Products

    In paragraphs 10 to 13 of our report, we referred to the need for Singapore to have a clear picture of the types and quality of students or citizens that we expect to emerge from the educational system. This we consider important because without this clear idea it will not be possible for us to design and formulate the curricula, syllabi, content of moral education, types of strategic school activities, content and depth of textbooks, etc. On the other hand, if we have clearer ideas about the end-products, then it will be more possible for us to consciously relate Curriculum, school activities and the education programme to our effort of

Column: 159

creating the types of citizens we would like to have in Singapore.

    We realise that this is not an easy job. We may not have that degree of acumen or insight. Or that the tools for this purpose may not be precise or reliable enough to define the end-products we desire. Nonetheless, we strongly urge that a serious attempt be made on this.

(4) Proposed Modification of the Streaming Programme

    We agree in principle on the need for the educational system to cater for late developers or slow learners. This is laudable. However, we are not too sure whether the three-stream structure - super bilingualists, average students, and monolingualists - is a good one. There are a number of problems which may arise and our views are expressed in paragraphs 42 to 50.

    We have suggested a modification to the Study Team's proposal and this is described in paragraphs 59 to 61. In essence, the modifications are as follows:-

    (i) We should have a two-stream structure instead of three. One is for the normal, bright student and the other the slower learner. As in the Study Team's recommendations, we suggest that streaming begins from Primary 4.

    (ii) For the slower learners, we recommend that the class be smaller. To these classes we should deploy more teaching and supportive facilities and more and better teachers. We strongly urge this on the principle and responsibility of "rendering best help to those who need it most." This must be our profound principle. If this is done, there is a greater chance for us to give closer attention and guidance to the weaker students.. It could help reduce the attrition rate. More positively, we will help the weaker ones to improve on their grades. We could even minimise parents' sensitivity in seeing their children being streamed to the monolingual stream or the average stream. We are mindful of possible resistance from

Column: 160

teachers who are deployed to teach the weaker class. Nonetheless, this problem can be solved if the approach is right and we know that there are still sufficient teachers who are enlightened enough to appreciate the value of this proposal.

    (iii) This two-stream structure will be continued in Primary 5 and 6 and where the weaker students make the grade, they could move laterally to the other stream.

    (iv) If after doing this, there are still weak students at Primary 6 who require the one-year extension, then let them have the additional year but we must continue the "beefing-up" support.

    (v) If after all these special efforts and the students still do not improve, then we have no other choice but to channel them to the Vocational and Industrial Training Board. When we do this, we know that we have tried our best to help them and we will send them to the VITB with a clearer conscience,

(5) Problems arising from Disparity in Performance amongst Primary Schools

    In paragraphs 54 to 57 of our report, we discussed the adverse implications of wide disparity of performance amongst primary schools. I have written to the Deputy Prime Minister on this matter. My constituents and I have requested the Ministry to develop a longer term policy to make all primary schools achieve comparable levels of performance. This should be done by deliberate "beefing-up" of the weaker schools with more and better teachers and facilities. We consider this policy a cardinal responsibility.

    If we succeed in this, then we could neutralise the distinction between "popular" and "unpopular" schools. We could also minimise the problems of teacher deployment and teacher demoralisation. Parents could also have less reason not to send their children to primary schools closer to their homes and, in certain cases, we could avoid the sensitive situation where there is the unwitting segregation of primary schools along racial lines.

Column: 161



(6) Home and Community Environment

    The Study Team's Report has essentially confined itself to the formal aspects of the education system - structure, administration, curriculum, streaming, teacher assessment, etc. We agree that these issues must be given priority attention. At the same time, it is important for us to recognise that the ability of the child to learn is not determined solely by the efficacy of the teaching techniques, learning processes in the school, or the school administration. There are other factors which affect the child's predisposition to be (or not to be) attentive, keen, interested or willing to pursue his studies with joy and deep commitment. Most of these factors arise from problems at home and the child's environment outside school. If we really want to help the child to develop, it is also important for us to minimise the influence that these adverse factors at home and the child's neighbourhood have on the child.

    We must give this subject more serious consideration, not just lip service. We must strive to understand the child, his environment, and all key factors which affect his educational performance. And we must consider this endeavour as an integral part of our education system.

The successful child; his mind and life pattern

    To me, a successful child is one who has the disposition or habit or discipline to want to study. He gets personal satisfaction in both the process or studying, and the impact of understanding and acquiring knowledge. Studying to him, therefore, becomes a purposeful effort and offers him a means to seek and experience self-worth and self-esteem.

    Such a state of mind or character gives the child a kind of momentum or inclination to pursue his studies as if it is part of his natural self. He becomes keen, serious and enthusiastic about his studies and he is faithful and conscientious about his daily

Column: 162

work. His life history is generally characterized by the following patterns:-

    (1) He is attentive and conscientious about school work.

    (2) He has parents or somebody in the home environment who gives him the deep inspiration and motivation.

    (3) He has very close friends who are also keen students and, together, they strengthen each other's vigour and keenness in studies.

    (4) To him, the "process of studying" becomes an "abiding companion" and there is a deep and private relationship between him and his studies.

Criticality of the child's environment

    These qualities of mind are things which must be consciously nurtured. Someone must do the "engineering", or to put it in another way, create the conditions, motivations and rules for the child to develop the positive attitudes, habits and discipline.

How can these personal values be nurtured

    We feel that this process is best done in the context of three situations:-

    (1) The family (ie. parents, elder brothers or sisters, uncles or aunts or even grand-elders). A family which shows concern, motivates and looks after the child's educational life, and creates conditions for the child to be "education-oriented" is the best guarantee for success.

    (2) The teachers in school. A dedicated teacher who teaches properly, guides and motivates the child is the biggest help we can hope for. The dedication of the teacher towards a student will indeed be more forthcoming if the student himself is hardworking, attentive, conscientious, enthusiastic and determined in pursuing his studies.

    (3) The child's immediate friends. A set of close friends who makes the "pursuit of education and knowledge" a joy in life to the child is the heartiest blessing we can grant the child.

Column: 163



    These three factors therefore are critical conditions which will determine whether the student is a self-starter and self-developer, or otherwise. If the conditions are positive, the student will succeed in developing the positive values. If they negate the inculcation of the positive values, then the student will fail to equip himself with the capacity, resilience and inclination to succeed in education.

Family setting

    The role of the family is most critical here because "success in education" rests on the initiative, determination and self-motivation of the child himself and these primary qualities are best nurtured in the context of the family setting, and done when the child is still at a tender age.

    In this regard, the family should:-

    (1) Create an environment and life style which gives high priority to education.

    (2) Help the child to become keen, serious and enthusiastic in his studies.

    (3) Train him to be faithful and conscientious in his daily studies.

    (4) Encourage him to:-

    (a) be up-to-date with his school work;

    (b) develop his self-confidence; and

    (c) broaden his knowledge and self-development.

To achieve these attributes, the family could consider the following measures:-

    (1) Parents and elders in the family should regularly converse with or enquire from the child about his school work. Such dialogues are best done during family meals, during rest time, immediately on the child's return from school, and immediately before or after the child's self-study at home, or even immediately before the child goes to sleep.

    (2) Parents could pray together with the child and immediately after the post-prayer, the father, uncle, grandfather, or elder

Column: 164

brother should talk to the child about the importance of education.

    (3) The child must be encouraged (or even disciplined) to have regular self-study at home every day. It is desirable to fix the commencement and end of the study hours. All other home activities (including TV programmes) must be modified, if not ceased, during these study hours.

    (4) If parents find it difficult to initiate the child's self-study at home, they may consider getting a tutor to be with the child at home to teach and, more importantly, to develop the habit and discipline of home self-study. This tutoring should, however, be limited in time - 6-12 months - because prolonged tutorship will make the child tutor-dependent.

    (5) Parents must encourage the child to look after his school books and other personal items properly and neatly. This is important to cultivate the child's respect for his books and education.

These are some examples which the family can do to develop the qualitative environment and home life-style to ensure the discipline and habit of consistent studying by the child.

    The basic requirements are simple: family sacrifice; priority of education; and joint effort in the family. The fulfilment of these requirements is difficult. But it must be done! There is no simpler way out. Without these, all other measures will bring about little impact.

Tuition Classes

    This brings me to the subject of tuition classes, an issue which I have been battling since July 1977. There are many tuition classes organised by community centres, mosques, civic and private organisations, purportedly intended to help poor performers. In a survey conducted in November 1978 on tuition classes conducted by 21 mosques and Malay civic organisations, we found that 2,081 students, most of them weak performers, attended tuition classes ranging from once to three times a week. I am not

Column: 165

against tuition classes, as such, especially if the number of pupils per class is small and they are guided by well-trained teachers. However, this is not so in many cases. Tuition classes do not always have qualified teachers. The classes are too large. There is more frolicking than serious study. By requiring the child to take tuition at these centres, (and now we also have classes in community centres) we may, unwittingly, be doing a disservice to the students and their families. The child and his family may also be discouraged from being more self-reliant or ensuring that the home environment is more conducive to consistent and conscientious study.

    I know the proponents of tuition classes would say that these classes are a necessary evil. They would say that these children's homes are too small or the home environment too distracting. To me, these are excuses. After all, overcrowding or distractions at home are not wholly physical problems. They are essentially human. A home becomes cramped or noisy because of family disorganisation, or because the family is unwilling to subject itself to self-restraint for the sake of the child.

    Sir, we have presented our views on this subject of tuition classes in paragraphs 66 to 69 of our report and we would like the Ministry to seriously review the quality of tuition classes conducted in civic organisations and community centres and to assess whether these tuition classes had really helped or will help the students in their studies.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, this is the first part of my presentation. I have a second part. But before I go on to the second part, may I, on behalf of my constituents and the teachers who teach the children in my constituency, wish the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education and his officials all success in their job of tackling all these most vexing problems of education. They should feel privileged for they are tackling a task which, if successfully done, will have such a profound

Column: 166

meaning to all Singaporeans. This, to me, is the best reward that the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education and his officials can look forward to. I humbly request that our views as presented in the paper are taken into account in the planning and implementation of the recommendations. At this juncture, may I, Mr Speaker, Sir, take this opportunity to express my most sincere thanks to the 109 principals, teachers and residents who contributed so much, and who have so sincerely and freely given me their views and advice.

    Now, the second part of my presentation.

Heredity and Intelligence

    I am glad that the Hon. Minister for Health mentioned the critical function of the brain in the learning process. I thought this should be obvious to all of us. After all, we learn and get educated because our brain learns and gets educated. So much work has been done on the brain and it is indeed a shame - a tragedy - if we ignore these studies or, worse still, brush them away as the work of quirks. We must not forget that "teaching" and "learning" are two different concepts. Teaching is a process; Learning is the result, the impact. The rules of teaching are different from the rules of learning. I thought the most obvious strategy is, first, for us to understand how the brain works. How it functions. How it absorbs learning. What makes it to function well. What impedes it.

    Leslie A. Hart in his pioneering book entitled How the Brain Works argues why and how schools operate in a way contrary to how the brain works and learns. His ground-breaking Proster Theory synthesizes solid findings in evolutionary biology, anthropology, neurophysiology, computer science, primotology, and ethology. Intensely "human" in his approach, Leslie Hart suggests the almost limitless capabilities of the human brain, if and when it is properly understood, respected, and utilised.

    Then there is so much research done on the correlation between heredity and intelligence, and also the roles of diet, family size, and environment as they promote or impede the growth of the brain. Heredity has

Column: 167

been said to be the fundamental determinant of intelligence. I am no expert on this subject but if the case of Sir Cyril Burt is taken as our reference point, we must be extremely cautious when making claims on heredity. When he died at the age of 88 in 1971, Sir Cyril Burt left behind an almost indisputable reputation as the most prestigious, powerful and influential psychologist who has convinced many people, renowned people, that heredity is the most important determining factor in human intelligence rather than the environment, or for that matter, any other factors. During his lifetime, he enjoyed a high reputation as a scholar of enormous charm and erudition but this was shattered by the findings of Leon Kamin, a Princeton psychologist.

    Kamin was one of the first researchers who scrutinised Sir Cyril's work in 1972. He found at least 20 glaring anomalies. One of the most important of these was the fact that Sir Cyril's statistical correlation between the IQ scores of identical twins in three separate statistics remained exactly the same to the third decimal point - this despite the fact that the number of twins in each of the three studies was different. Kamin suspected that such statistical correlation was virtually impossible. In his further studies on Sir Cyril's work, Kamin found similar errors, some of them dating back as far as 1909. At about the same time, another researcher, Arthur R. Jansen, from Berkeley, who was a strong proponent of the heredity claim, found himself puzzled by Sir Cyril's statistics and, mind you, Jansen was one of Sir Cyril's proteges. Even Sir Cyril's co-authors, Miss Margaret Howard and Miss J. Conway, were found to be persons who never existed. The London Sunday Times charged that Sir Cyril invented these persons.

     Encik Mansor Haji Sukaimi: Sir, I will do it later, as I have left my file at home. But if

the Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour is interested in this study, I would be very happy to give him a copy.

     Encik Mansor Haji Sukaimi: If you are of the view, Mr Speaker, Sir, that this particular reference to the London Sunday Times is contrary to the Standing Orders, then I beg leave to withdraw it. Thank you very much, Sir. I also thank very much the Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour.

    The husband and wife team, Professors Alan and Anne Clarke of Hull University, who worked with Sir Cyril in the 1940s and the 1950s, suspected his integrity even then. The mystery of how much, if any, of Sir Cyril's work was fraudulent and why, will probably never be solved. Six chestful of papers were burnt immediately after his death and many of his original works were thought to have been among them.

    This battle between "naturists", and the environmentalists, or "nurturists", will certainly continue. The lesson to learn is that we must be extra cautious when making claims about genetic determinism. It could be extremely dangerous, considering its frightening underlying tones and its fatalistic meaning.

    In the case of Cyril Burt, he was known to be a man of enormous charm and erudition. He was also famous for being a fearsome figure, an autocrat of the old school but wrapped in a most charming style. The eminent geneticist, L.S. Penrose, who had known Sir Cyril for 30 years, once said of Sir Cyril Burt:

    "I don't believe a word the old rogue says, but, by God, I admire the way he says it".

Brain research has now moved more and more to the less discomforting issues - how diet affects brain growth; how size of family or spacing of children promotes intelligence growth; how a rich stimulating environment, meaningful to the child, can boost up the

Column: 169

breadth, depth and capacity of the child's brain. And thank God, this is the trend.

    The Hon. Minister for Health has rightly brought to our attention the critical growth processes that occur during the first two to three years of the child after birth. To me, this is one of the most profound statements that can ever be said during this debate on education policy.

    Roger Lewin, in his excellent review article, entitled "Starved Brains", presents research work which confirms Dr Toh Chin Chye's statements. In that review, it is stated that research has shown that the brain grows in two stages. First, between the 10th and 1 8th week of pregnancy, the adult number of nerve cells develops. Second, about the beginning of the 20th week, the brain's packing cells begin to appear, followed by the production of the insulating material (myelin) that coats the long fibres along which the nerve cells send their messages. This second stage, the research shows, continues for at least two years after birth. Myelination progresses at a lower rate until the age of four years. The second stage, known as the brain-growth spurt, represents the most vulnerable period of brain development. It is the critical period when inadequate nutrition and lack of stimulation inflict the most lasting damage.     Too much emphasis on the utilitarian approach to education may create a distorted

Column: 176

sense of value in our younger generation. It will breed the habit of equating everything with money. They will try to place everything in terms of international market value. For instance, when he has to choose a friend, he would ask: "What can I get out of him or her?" He befriends a person because of his position, status or wealth and not because he has an affection or respect for him as a person of charm or character. What is the price of loyalty? How much is loyalty worth? What is the price of honesty, integrity, diligence and even patriotism? He is loyal to Singapore just because she provides him with a job, shelter and comfort. The moment these utilitarian values are gone, he migrates. We want our younger generation to be Singaporeans who are not only useful citizens but have strong moral character and who care for the welfare of his community and nation. Imparting knowledge to pass examinations, and later to do a job, these are important. Is he, when the need arises, a good soldier, ready to defend his country, and so protect his wife and children, and his fellow citizens? Is he filial, respectful to elders, law-abiding, humane, and responsible? Does he take care of his wife and children and his parents? Is he a good neighbour and a trustworthy friend?     We may be well-off in the utilitarian aspect of education, but humanitarian-wise, we can learn a lot from our ASEAN and Asian neighbours. In Central Java, for instance, from a tender age, a child is instilled with the Javanese traditional sense of moral values: the importance of self-discipline, the virtues of humility, tolerance, comradeship, bravery, sacrifice, honour and dignity. All these

Column: 177

through wayang kulit. As the child sees the favourite shadows on a screen and listens to the stories of Ramayana or Mahabaratha, beautifully related by the dalang, the moral lessons are sunk home. His character is being moulded and he knows his place in society and the role he should play. educated in the Chinese stream in Penang. I was the product of an education system described by the Prime Minister as outside the control of Government. The school which I studied, Chung Ling High School (    ), was China-oriented in those days. I was a British Subject but nobody treated me as a British Subject. I was treated as a Chinese. We had our own source of revenue, syllabi, teachers, principals and management committees. Chung Ling, however, was different from other secondary schools throughout Malaya in those days in that it was bilingual in character giving emphasis on Chinese during the first three years and English on the 2nd three years, Bilingualism was successfully implemented in the early thirties when its advocators could be branded as colonial stooges. I must point out, however, that when I entered Chung Ling from a village Chinese school in Butterworth, my knowledge of English was very poor and I flipped my English/Chinese and Chinese/English dictionaries so often that they were torn to pieces by the end of the term. I do not think it is that difficult for Chinese school students to study English. It is a matter of providing the right environment and climate, such as what we are trying to do - immersion - the right teachers with dedication and most important of all, enough time for a system to prove its worth. I am surprised to find that the Education Ministry chose to use English as a medium of instruction in Science and Technology, and then was disappointed that it did not help to improve the standard of English of Chinese school students. I would have thought that the best way of learning English is to make the students read novels, poetry and litera-

Column: 180

ture instead of Science, Mathematics or Technology. The teaching of Science and Technology is a matter of gathering facts and thinking scientifically and not linguistically. In many cases, the teachers who taught Science and Technology, I was told, were not competent in English and were teaching the subjects in Mandarin. It was not so much the failure of students to learn English, but the failure of methods and choice of teachers. I am therefore in favour of the recommendations in the Report to devote the first three years of primary education to the teaching of languages.

    The speaking of dialect at home, to my mind, is not a hindrance to the study of Mandarin. It may, on the other hand, help the study of Mandarin because after all, the same character is used to spell out dialects including Mandarin. It was a matter of different spelling of the same word. It may be difficult for those who are over 35 years of age to start learning the Chinese language for I admit that Chinese is one of the most difficult languages in the world, particularly for adults. The experience may not be so bitter if one learns from a tender age. I am afraid I may not agree with the Member for Punggol and the Minister for Health. I have also no doubt that

Column: 181

our people will become bilingual if we spell out the prerequisites for entry into the civil service and, better still, a prerequisite in the climb to hierarchy in the civil service.     Another point I would like to raise on our education policy concerns the crammed curriculum of our schools. The childhood days of our younger generation are most unenviable. There has been a tendency to cram our children with facts and figures, and knowledge of all kinds, leaving them very little time to think or play. Cramming of borrowed language may not necessarily make a person wise. It reminds me of my trip to Peking when I saw how the Peking ducks were fed by a machine. I could not imagine how the ducks could enjoy eating when the food was rammed down their throats. Crammed knowledge may be indigestible. In my younger days, and I think in the younger days of most of my senior colleagues, despite bilingualism, I had the time to play marbles, fly kites, catch fighting fish and do a lot of thinking after school, and also play music. We did not have a crammed curricula. Nowadays children hardly have time to sing a tune or know how to sing a tune. In some cases, music and ballet lessons are thrown in because of parental pressure, leaving the children insufficient time for sleep and rest This trend, I am afraid, will produce in our society a crop of young people, crammed with borrowed knowledge but unable to think for themselves, least of all, wise. Textbooks do not provide him with answers to solve human problems. Some for lack of moral stamina committed suicide, others went into drug

Column: 182

abuse or vandalism because they could not rise to the expectations of their parents. It is dangerous for parents to expect too much from their children. They want their children to become "dragons". If we accept the importance of bilingual education and moral education as the objectives of our education system and agree with the concept of streaming, then logically we must accept, at least in principle, the recommendations of Dr Goh's Study Team, as outlined in Chapter 6, paragraphs 2 -3, of the Report. Here, I should indicate that I support the proposed revised education system in principle. Nevertheless, I would like to identify some problem areas relating to bilingual education, and make some comments on the implementation of policies and proposals in relation to moral education and streaming.

    The implementation of our bilingual education policies has posed a number of difficulties. These difficulties have accounted for the unsatisfactory results reported in Chapter 1 of the report. First, there is the question of incentives. We need not persuade parents how important the English Language is to their children. They know that if they want their children to have promising career prospects, and to earn a decent living, the children must achieve a certain level of proficiency in English. On the other hand, there is no such built-in incentive for the learning of the other three official languages.

Column: 206

True, the learning of these three languages has been linked with cultural and traditional values. But, Sir, a deficiency in these languages, including the risk of deculturalisation, does not incur obvious disadvantages. I believe that many English-speaking monolinguals do not even feel culturally deprived. Personally, I know of a few English-educated Chinese who are even proud of the fact that they cannot use chopsticks because they are, in the words of one of them, "very European". Given the materialistic outlook, pragmatic thinking and the somewhat calculating attitudes of Singaporeans, we should expect and cannot blame parents for sending their children to English schools, even at the risk of deculturalisation. Sir, the data on the differences in the median monthly incomes between the Chinese educated reservists and the English educated reservists, quoted by the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education two days ago, only serve to further convince these parents that they have made the right and rational choice for their children. To encourage the learning of Chinese, Malay or Tamil as a second language (CL2, ML2, TL2), there must be incentives for students to do so. The minimum proficiency in the second language at the GCE 'A' level as part of the requirements for admission into University, and later, perhaps for entry into the Administrative Service, may provide such an incentive. However, it must be cautioned that in the case of CL2, these measures do not necessarily make it a living language.

    This brings me to the special problems confronting Chinese students who try to achieve proficiency in both the English and the Chinese languages. The use of dialect has posed a problem. The difficulty for these students is not just that they have to learn three languages - English and Chinese at school and a spoken language - dialect - at home. The problem also arises from the fact that dialects interfere with the learning of English and Chinese, particularly in sentence construction. It suffices here for me to quote a few examples. The Hon. Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour has told some of us the conversation

Column: 207

he overheard between two nurses. "Johnny is the worst type!". "Why?" "He said he come he don't come type!". This kind of expression is very common. I have come across students from a technical tertiary educational institution using such expressions as "cannot don't go la!" and "mother don't give me come!". Similarly, the learning of Mandarin is also affected by dialect. Tou xian, wo kan mei you (    ) is a direct translation from Hokkien, whereas Bao zhi you mei you mai (    ) is a translation from the Cantonese expression. Sir, for these reasons, it is necessary to encourage our students and young people to use Mandarin as often as possible instead of dialects and parents must, as far as possible, converse likewise with their children in Mandarin, if they do not want to hear from their own children the type of expressions I have just quoted.

    Further, for Chinese students, there is the complexity of written Chinese. It is true that simplified Chinese characters have created some confusion. Just a few days ago, I heard a secondary student reciting a poem of the Tang Dynasty, xi chu yang guan wu di ren (    ) (instead of xi chu yang guan wu gu ren (    ). Mr Speaker, Sir, for the information of Members, "di ren" means enemy and "gu ren" means old friends. The necessity of having simplified characters could also be demonstrated by the following examples: a student with a name Ting I San (    ) has only six strokes to write, whereas his poor classmate Kwan wan Fong (    ) has to make a total of 50 strokes just to complete writing his name. I counted the number of strokes of the name of the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education. I think the total number of strokes was about 36. In the old days, one of the punishments favoured by the Chinese school teachers was to ask the misbehaved student to write his name 100 times. Just imagine how painful it was for Mr Kwan. Each time it is 50 strokes. On the other hand, if Mr Kwan knows simplified characters, he needs to write only 13 strokes (    ). For these practical reasons, I support the use of simplified Chinese characters. However,

Column: 208

there should be a single, unified list of these simplified characters which could be universally adopted by the Chinese newspapers, EPB textbooks and other Chinese publications.

The Managing Director suggested that people who master 2,000-2,500 Chinese characters should be able to read Chinese newspapers. This is confirmed by the General Manager of the Nanyang Siang Pau, who informed me that the more commonly used Chinese characters in his papers number about 2,500. If literacy in Chinese language means the ability to read and understand what are in the newspapers, then the 60% of primary students would just need to learn some 400 characters in a school year, and for the remaining 40%, the number of Chinese characters to learn per year is even less. This is not an impossible task to achieve.

    At the secondary level, the Report has recommended the lowering of CL (Chinese Language) in all the streams. For the top 8% students in the special bilingual stream, they have to learn both ELl (English as a First Language) and CL1 (Chinese as a First Language) with the standard of the CL1 adjusted downward. For the next 31% of students who are in the normal bilingual stream, the standard of CL2, again, is to be adjusted downward. The remaining 41% of

Column: 209

students in the ordinary stream will learn ELl and CL3 (Chinese as a Lower Second Language). All these are, presumably, aimed at reducing the load in learning CL. However, I am not convinced that the time saved through the lowering of CL will necessarily result in the improvement of the standard of their English language. What is more puzzling is that the learning of a foreign language such as German or French or even Russian, is even recommended (Chapter 6, para 2.1.1) for the top 8% of students. Sir, I wonder if these brilliant students have excess capacity and time to learn this extra foreign language. It appears to be too premature a move anyway. I think the Member for Serangoon Gardens will bear me out on this. In the graduate schools of Australia or America, we normally learn one or two foreign languages like German and French, and forget about them after the examination. It will be more fruitful for the top 8% students to learn the regular CL1 instead of the diluted CL1.

    What is really needed is not the overall lowering of CL. The solution lies in the building up of a pool of effectively bilingual teachers who have gone through the two systems themselves and consequently, know how to correlate, transpose and interpose the two different languages. If there are only few effective language teachers, the system will not produce many good bilingual students. Without the supply of enough bilingual students, there will not be enough effective language teachers and defective language teaching will be perpetuated. To break this vicious cycle, the Ministry of Education should try to retain the services of effective bilingual teachers, who could easily be lost to the private sector and other Government departments. The Public Service Commission should try to channel more bilingual graduates to the teaching profession by appropriately adjusting upwards the terms and conditions of service.

    Members have raised many points on moral education. Sir, I simply want to make some observations. There is a basic incon-

Column: 210

sistency in our system. On the one hand, we expect our education system to produce good citizens and people with good character. On the other hand, our elitist education system in particular, and our emphasis on meritocracy in general, assesses our people not in terms of their conduct or behaviour, but rather by their academic qualifications, performance and efficiency in carrying out a specific task. Sometimes, aggressiveness and arrogance are even regarded as signs of a strong and dynamic personality. Perhaps, this is one of the reasons why we have so often heard of white-collar crimes committed by our well-educated professionals. It is therefore gratifying to note that the Study Team has given moral education a rightful place in the curriculum. However, let us have no illusions. Moral teaching is not just imparting knowledge; even students could recite the "do's and dont's" in their lessons perfectly and reciting the stories of Yue Fei, Wen Tian Xiang (    ) vividly does not necessarily mean that the moral teaching is successful. The litmus test is whether these students have imbibed the moral values in them and have used them to serve as the inner mode of conduct, guiding their behaviour all the time.

    To reinforce the moral lessons they learn from the stories, folklores and texts, all teachers, not just teachers of moral education, should set good personal examples. If they do not even greet each other in school, how do you expect the students to greet them? The parents' examples are equally, if not, more influential. I agree wholeheartedly that the family is the most important factor in moral education. If the students are taught to be respectful and courteous to one another, but when they come home they find their parents using abusive language on each other, how could you make the students believe in what have been taught in school? Similarly, they are told not to gamble, but if mahjong (    ) games go on in their home every weekend, how can we tell them that gambling is undesirable? These cancelling games between school and family must be stopped.

Column: 211

In moral education for children, we must also educate the parents.

    Finally, on streaming, Sir, I accept the principle of streaming. Streaming of students is better than the present singular system. We have provided equal opportunity of education to children of schooling age, yet we have to accept the fact that not all are equally good in learning. We have to adjust the system according to the needs of different categories of students with different capacities, rather than expecting all of them to adjust to the singular system.

    However, we have to face the reality squarely and that is streaming will bring about some undesirable consequences. As expressed by several Members, because of high expectations, parents will pressurise their children even harder, never allowing them to slip into the bottom category. I wonder how many parents have sleepless nights when their children are taking PSLE or GCE examinations? We have also to ask whether streaming will also aggravate the tendency towards excessive competition, and advance the rat-race to an early age. Parents will never accept that their children are inferior to anyone. If their children do not perform well, they will blame the teachers, the school, the Hon. Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education, or even the Government. I also share the concern of several Members that streaming will lead to the average and below-average students having to live through life with a stigma on them, just like in the Brave New World. All these are implementation problems; some could be solved, others could not be solved. But in any circumstances, parents should be adequately consulted and their views sought. Therefore, I support the Motion that flexibility in implementation, particularly in accommodating the wishes of parents, be given. Officers of the Ministry of Education must bear in mind that in streaming, they are dealing with sensitive human souls, who have pride, esteem and feeling; they should not be sorted out like computer cards by a sorter. Similarly, the views and opinions of principals and teachers who are in constant contact with the pupils and their parents

Column: 212

must be seriously sought. I therefore support paragraph (3) of the Motion standing in the name of the Hon. Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education.

    Sir, no system is perfect; notwithstanding the tremendous implementation problems which have been discussed and highlighted in this House, the revised system appears to be workable. The solutions to these problems and the success or failure of the proposed system will depend largely on the quality, commitment and attitude of principals and teachers on the one hand and the understanding and co-operation of parents on the other. Much has been said on the low morale of principals and teachers and many hon. Members, including myself, have urged the Government to revise upward the terms and conditions of our teachers and to give them proper recognition. These are the logical steps to take if we expect to have qualified and dedicated teachers and the revised education system to be workable.

    Sir, we Parliamentarians also have our share of responsibility. We should constantly help to monitor the implementation of the recommendations of the new education policies and give the Ministry of Education the feedback we have from the ground. One way to keep the Ministry officials on their toes all the time and provide a direct channel of communication between MPs on the one hand, and teachers and parents on the other hand, is to have a Parliamentary Standing Committee on Education. However, the Ministry of Education may complain of too much or too frequent interference from the Committee. This will probably happen as everyone seems to be an expert on education, looking at the issue from the political, economic, social, historical or even biological and medical viewpoint. The next alternative therefore will be for the Ministry to collate the suggestions and criticisms made by hon. Members during this debate and for the Minister of Education to report to Parliament periodically on the progress and problems encountered in the implementation of the revised education system. Thus, Sir, I support the amendments standing in the names of the Hon. Minister for Health

Column: 213

and Hon. Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour.

     Mr Lim Chee Onn (Bukit Merah): Mr Speaker, Sir, as one of the tail-end speakers in this debate, I shall attempt to give a broad-brush view of the revised education structure rather than delve into cracks and crevices of the proposed revision because I feel these cracks and crevices have been adequately covered by my colleagues who spoke before me.

    There is no doubt that the education process is a complex one as otherwise it would not have foiled the best minds in the land for the past 20 years. There were, of course, other priorities such as industrialisation and economic development and later defence.

    The best way to analyse a complex problem is to break it up into its components and then examine each part in turn. The Mindef Study Team has attempted to do this and in my opinion has fared remarkably well in identifying the short-comings of each component of our educational system.

    Measures have been recommended to remedy the defects of each part of the system, and no doubt, these measures, if implemented judiciously and carefully, will produce the desired results. However, it will be prudent to reassemble once again in the mind's eye the reconstructed parts prior to execution to see if the improved system as a whole serves our purpose and is capable of meeting our objectives.

    The primary objective of our education system is to nurture each and every one of our young people into a loyal and patriotic citizen with the qualities which will stand him in good stead in caring for the community and our nation as a whole.

    The emphasis on moral education in the revised education system is therefore rightly placed. In addition, we ought to tap from the vast cultural reservoir which provided our

Column: 214

forefathers with the strength and tenacity to build this nation of ours. It would indeed be foolish if we did not make full use of this scarce resource in our possession. However, to do this effectively, our children must be given at least a working knowledge of their mother tongue. It is for this reason that we have pursued the bilingual policy so relentlessly. It is not easy to achieve this objective. There are many obstacles, but we must succeed, otherwise our future generations will be cut off from our cultural heritage from which our society can draw strength.

    The acquisition of knowledge and skill is the other facet of our education process. Not surprisingly, this aspect is the main source of concern for parents. They feel that possession of the right skills and high academic performance are the passport to good jobs and secure livelihood for their children. This pre-occupation of parents with the achievements of their children is not unexpected as every parent naturally hopes that his children will do well in life.

    However, parents must accept the fact that children do not all possess equal capabilities nor indeed similar interests. In fact, this dissimilarity is evident even amongst children from the same family.

    Given this nature of things, the objective of the recommended education system to provide every child the best opportunity to develop his or her full potential is a laudable and correct one. The essence of the recommendations made by the Mindef Study Team is captured in its expressed intention "to seek ways of giving half a loaf when a whole loaf would choke" (paragraph 3.2.1, page 6-4 of the Report). The Study has confirmed what is probably obvious to all but accepted by few, especially parents and purists and that is "different children have different capacities to acquire knowledge" through a formal education system.

    It is precisely this reluctance to accept what is essentially a fact of life that has led to an education system that subjects the less able students to the same regime of learning drawn up for the brighter ones. This

Column: 215

unsatisfactory state of affairs is further aggravated by the fact that for a large proportion of our students, the language of communication at home differs from that used and taught in the classrooms.

    While it is true that half a loaf is better than choking on a full loaf, parents in many cases will be unwilling to accept that their children are only capable of consuming that much and no more. At the same time, parents will always be nursing a nagging doubt that their children have not been given the best opportunity to develop their children's potential to the fullest.

    Given this natural reaction of parents, it is incumbent upon the Ministry of Education to explain fully, clearly and in very simple terms why the recommended system had been drawn up, how it will ensure that every child will be able to develop to his fullest potential and the length of time it will take to accomplish these objectives.

    The Report on the Ministry of Education 1978 presented by the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education provides some answers to these questions. Unfortunately, the Report cannot be easily digested by the average parent or even by all teachers. The Ministry of Education should consider therefore explaining the rationale for and details of the proposed education structure to parents and teachers in a series of forums. With better understanding, there will be greater acceptance. Their responses will also help the Ministry when they draw up implementation details.

    With the variety of environments to which different children are exposed and the wide range of inclinations and abilities displayed by children, the practical difficulties encountered in implementation of the proposed education scheme are considerable.

    It will help to reassure parents if implementation plans are executed only after careful evaluation of their impact on children and their performance. Minor changes and adjustments are unavoidable and indeed are necessary to improve and fine-tune the

Column: 216

system. But there ought not to be any drastic policy changes which will throw the whole education system into disarray. Once our citizens are convinced that the proposed system is the best, taking into consideration both our national long term objectives and the perceived ambitions of parents for their children, there should be no reversal of policies unless there is clear evidence that the results are far from desirable. Frequent policy changes will only create doubts in the public mind as to the veracity of the Ministry's claims.

    It will take many years before the fruits of our labour can be seen. It will require the concerted effort of the whole Government, not just the Ministry of Education alone, to ensure success. In fact, most Ministries could, through their respective policies help to create a social and physical environment conducive to the proper moral, mental and physical development of our children.

    The mass media's role is unquestionable in the context of language learning. The impact of TV, radio and newspapers on the development of language ability among children cannot be over-emphasised. Those people who are responsible for these communication media have to put in a conscious effort to make language learning a less onerous task. It is towards this end that the Ministry of Culture can direct some of its policies.

    Much can be done to improve the environment for children to help them in their pursuit of skills and knowledge. The Report has stated clearly that the home environment does affect the performance of children in school. There is no doubt that some who have the intellectual capability to handle the academic course, may find their progress hampered by a poor home environment.

    During the recent debate on the Government's financial estimates, it was made very clear by many Members that there is a tremendous demand for study space, and that the present facilities are inadequate to meet such demands. Column: 217

provide improved facilities for our younger generation.

    These are some examples of the concerted effort that is needed before the objectives of our education system can be attained. I would therefore like to suggest that a high-powered inter-Ministry Committee be set up to examine the contributions which each Ministry can make towards creating a better social and physical environment for our children and hence assisting them to achieve their full potential.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I am fully aware that there are already over 100 committees in existence in the Ministry of Education. In fact, I am most reluctant to add on to that number. I believe that a co-ordinated effort will bring about results that much quicker compared to ad hoc decisions and individual requests for assistance.
